I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Dialogue between the Government of Viet Nam and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
has highlighted the importance of providing timely and continued support to the government to 
improve project financial management under decentralization. During the country programming 
confirmation  mission  in  February  2012,  the  government  confirmed  its  request  for  capacity 
development  technical  assistance  (TA)  from  ADB  for  the  Supporting  Project  Financial 
Management Decentralization (Phase 3).1 The concept paper for the TA was approved on 12 
March 2012. An ADB fact-finding mission fielded from 21 March to 2 April 2012 to prepare the 
TA  reached  an  understanding  with  the  government  on  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since Viet Nam’s attainment of the status of a middle-income country in 2010, its access 
to traditional concessional official development assistance (ODA) has diminished. ADB and the 
government  recognize,  however,  that  continued  growth  and  poverty  reduction  through  the 
successful implementation of the 5-year Socio-Economic Development Plan, 2011–2015 will 
require costly structural reform and significant infrastructure investments to address bottlenecks. 
Faced with the increasing cost of finance and growing investment needs, the government must 
improve the efficiency of externally financed public investments. This will entail improvements to 
the project financial management in the central government and local governments alike and 
enhanced external debt management that mitigates the risks of external borrowing. 
 
3.  Increasing the economic and social returns on public investments requires building the 
capacity of government officials responsible for the financial appraisal of investment projects.  
Currently, central and local government officials lack the capacity to conduct by themselves 
effective project financial analysis. To strengthen their ownership of projects and programs, they 
need  to  improve  their  knowledge  and  skills  regarding  project  financial  analysis,  especially 
toward  improving  the  efficiency  and  viability  of  proposed  investments.  Improving  such 
knowledge and skills is also critical for government officials responsible for appraising and 
approving projects.  Additionally, the lack of clear guidelines on project financial preparation and 
appraisal,  and  the  fragmented  legal  framework  for  financial  management  during  project 
implementation, further made it difficult for staff to properly and consistently conduct project 
financial management. 
 
4.  Under new conditions as a middle-income country, the Government of Viet Nam is 
committed to the continued improvement of the legal and institutional framework for effectively 
managing external borrowings in line with the Law on Public Debt Management, which was 
declared effective on 1 January 2010. The Prime Minister issued Decision 106/QD-TTg of 19 
January 2012 on Approval of the Strategic Framework for Attracting, Managing, and Utilizing 
ODA and Other Concessional Sources from 2011 to 2015.3 In line with Decision 106/QD-TTg,

the  government  plans  to  amend  various  decrees,  circulars,  and  regulations,  which  will 
significantly affect the mobilization and management of ODA and other, less-concessional funds. 
Specifically,  the  government  is  currently  amending  Decree  131/2006/ND/CP,  on  ODA 
management and utilization, to cover both ODA and less-concessional funds and incorporate 
recent recommendations toward improving the management and utilization of ODA and less-
concessional funds. Recent improvements to the legal and regulatory framework for ODA and 
less-concessional funds require further refinements to the legal framework and procedures for 
project financial management.  
 
5.  Since 2000, ADB had provided assistance to the government through TA for Improving 
Project Financial Management through Decentralization (footnote 1) and TA for Supporting 
Financial Management Decentralization (footnote 1). The government greatly appreciated the 
manual  on  financial  issues  of  ODA  projects  developed  under  the  earlier  TA  and  several 
recommendations made under the latter TA. Nevertheless, changes in circumstances require 
that the manual be updated and improved in line with the government’s latest regulations on 
ODA  and  less-concessional  borrowing.  Additionally,  the  government’s  fragmented  legal 
documents  governing  the  financial  management  of  ODA  and  less-concessional  borrowing 
require refinement and consolidation.  
 
6.  The country operations business plan, 2012–2014 confirms the need to respond to the 
changing requirements of the country’s long-term growth and development and to strengthen 
portfolio performance.4  ADB’s newly approved country partnership strategy, 2012–2015 cites 
the strategic thrust to support Viet Nam’s transition to status as an upper-middle-income country 
through three pillars: inclusive growth, environmental sustainability, and improved efficiency.5  In 
line with the country operations business plan and the country partnership strategy, the TA will 
help the government enhance the efficiency of externally financed public investments and, in 
particular, strengthen the government’s effective mobilization and utilization of ADB resources 
by (i) enhancing the capacity of government staff involved in project financial management, 
specifically in the financial preparation and appraisal of projects to optimize the utilization of 
borrowed funds and ensure debt repayment, and (ii) helping the government develop a manual 
on the financial management of ODA and less-concessional borrowing, as well as sector-
specific guidelines on the financial preparation and appraisal of ADB-funded investment projects. 
Support from ADB is critical to the government’s effective and sustainable use of overseas 
borrowings in general and ADB assistance in particular. It fully aligns with an evaluation study 
recommendation to provide project-level capacity-building support in the sectors and subsectors 
where  project  preparation  and  implementation  are  decentralized.6 The  TA  is  necessary  to 
provide continuity in ADB’s support to the government in project financial management under 
Viet Nam’s new circumstances. The TA will build on the results achieved in previous TA projects, 
further institutionalize and mainstream procedures for managing project finances, and develop 
tools and provide the necessary capacity building for better project financial management.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be the more effective utilization of ADB resources by the 
Government of Viet Nam. The outcome of the TA will be improved financial preparation and 
management of ADB-funded projects in Viet Nam.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities   
8.  To achieve the expected outcome, the TA will deliver three outputs: (i) sector-specific 
guidelines on project financial preparation and appraisal for ADB-funded investment projects, 
(ii) a well-defined and streamlined manual on financial management issues of ODA and less-
concessional borrowing, and (iii) skills and knowledge of government staff on project financial 
management enhanced, particularly regarding project financial preparation and appraisal. By 
focusing on improving the financial preparation and management of ADB-funded projects, the 
TA will complement TA for Support to Improve Portfolio Performance and Aid Effectiveness, 
focusing on improving the performance of ADB-funded projects in Viet Nam.7  
9.  The TA will undertake a series of workshops and seminars for consultation and to 
disseminate TA-generated products. To facilitate the issuance of the guidelines and manual 
under outputs 1 and 2, and to support capacity building under output 3, consultation workshops 
will be conducted with key stakeholders and development partners to discuss the draft TA 
products  and related training  materials.  Meetings  with  line  agencies,  local  authorities,  and 
project management units at different levels will be organized for the consultants and the 
working group in the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to ensure a practical approach to generating TA 
products. Capacity building is an important component of the TA. To ensure the sustainability of 
the project, trainers will be trained and the MOF will regularly update digital files of the TA 
products and advise stakeholders of the updates. TA outputs and main activities to achieve 
each output are provided below. 
10.  Output 1: Sector-specific guidelines on financial preparation and appraisal for 
ADB-funded  investment  projects  developed.  Guidelines  on  financial  preparation  and 
appraisal for ADB-funded investment projects will be developed under the TA and based on a 
review of government’s regulations and procedures on project financial analysis and appraisal, 
ADB guidelines on Financial Management and Analysis of Projects,8 and hands-on experience 
in selecting and preparing ADB-funded investment projects in Viet Nam and in other lower-
middle-income  countries.  It  will  provide  the  basic  concepts,  indicators,  principles,  and 
procedures of the financial analysis of ADB-funded investment projects including project cost 
estimates, financial planning, and financial cost–benefit analyses. As investments in each sector 
will  have  different  objectives,  designs,  and  implementation  approaches,  the  guidelines  will

PPSSF to ensure that capacity building in central government ministries and local governments is complementary 
and effective.

provide examples specific to sectors. The guidelines will be a reference for government officials 
involved  in  preparing  and  appraising  ADB-funded  projects,  helping  them  to  analyze  more 
proactively,  independently,  and  effectively  the  financial  aspects  of  ADB-funded  investment 
projects  and  optimally  select  them.  Additionally,  the  guidelines  will  provide  checklists  for 
financial analyses and appraisals, including summaries of financial analysis and review steps 
and benchmarks on financial indicators that government staff can refer to for demonstrating and 
ensuring the financial viability of the projects. Financial indicators are to be reviewed and 
updated as necessary throughout the project cycle to ensure early warning of project problems 
and timely corrective action. TA consultants will help develop the guidelines in consultation with 
stakeholders. 
 
11.  Output 2: A well-defined and streamlined manual on financial management issues 
of ODA and less-concessional borrowing developed. The manual on financial management 
issues generated under the TA will cover financial issues at different stages of the project cycle, 
including budget planning, disbursement, expenditure control, project accounting and auditing, 
processing  changes  in  financial  allocations  during  project  implementation,  preparing  final 
accounts,  project  asset  management,  and  taxation  and  related  issues.  It  will  update  and 
improve  the manual generated  under the TA for  Improving  Project  Financial  Management 
through Decentralization (footnote 1) and incorporate recommendations made under the TA for 
Supporting Financial Management Decentralization (footnote 1). TA consultants will help review 
and incorporate updated regulations and procedures from the government and development 
partners alike. The manual will be a reference clarifying various procedures and processes in 
project financial management that government staff will be able to use toward the consistent 
and sound financial management of ODA and less-concessional borrowing.  
12.  Output  3:  Skills  and  knowledge  of  government  staff  on  project  financial 
management  enhanced,  particularly  regarding  project  financial  preparation  and 
appraisal. Under this output, the TA will support the training of at least 350 government staffers. 
Training materials will be developed using the guidelines and manual generated under outputs 1 
and 2. Trainers will be trained to ensure the sustainability of the project. The first batch of 
courses will target central and local government staff involved in preparing and appraising ADB-
funded projects. The second batch of courses will be conducted for government staff in project 
financial management in general. Piloted training courses in project financial management will 
be conducted for the staff of ADB-funded projects in selected sectors.  
13.  As the executing agency, MOF will work closely with line ministries, local authorities, and 
project management units to nominate staff to participate in the training-of-trainers courses and 
ensure that the trained staff efficiently disseminate the skills and knowledge acquired through 
trainings. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000, of which $580,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide in-
kind counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff remuneration, office accommodation, 
and administrative and logistic support. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 
2.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements

5
15.  MOF will, as the executing agency, assign a vice minister to guide implementation and 
establish a project management unit to oversee implementation. The representative of the 
External Finance & Debt Management Department will be the director of project management 
unit and focal point for coordinating TA activities. A working group of officials from MOF will be 
established to work with the TA consultants during implementation. The working group will meet 
quarterly or as required to monitor TA implementation progress and ensure that TA objectives 
are achieved. ADB representatives will be invited to the meetings if necessary.  
16.  The TA will require 6 person-months of international consultant inputs and 20 person-
months of national consultant inputs. An international consultant will be required for project 
financial management including project financial preparation, financial analysis and appraisal, 
and developing models for effective project financial management. Two national consultants will 
be required. Consultants will be engaged individually in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will prepare and submit the following reports and 
documents to MOF and ADB: (i) an inception report 1 month after fielding, (ii) an interim report 
3–4 months after fielding, and (iii) draft and final completion reports upon TA completion, 
covering TA implementation and impact.  
17.  The disbursement of TA proceeds will be managed in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time) using an advance 
payment facility. TA-financed equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and handed over to the executing agency 
upon TA completion. 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from 15 December 2012 to 15 December 
2014. ADB will send inception and review missions and participate in tripartite meetings with the 
government and the consultant team. TA outputs and outcome will be jointly monitored and 
evaluated by MOF and ADB during inception, midterm review and final review missions. Tracer 
studies  after  TA  completion  will  track  the  uptake  of  the  training  courses  by  reviewing 
government staff capacity in project financial management. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $580,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Supporting Project Financial Management Decentralization 
(Phase 3), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Expert on Project Financial Management—Team Leader (6 person-
months, intermittent)  
1.  The team leader shall have extensive experience in public project financial management 
and hands-on experience in lower-middle-income and other developing countries in the region 
in  public  finance  and  project  financial  management  in  particular.  He  or  she  shall  have  a 
postgraduate degree in finance, accounting, or economics; strong analytical skills; and good 
teaching and presentation skills. Understanding of the project financial management guidelines 
of  international  financial  agencies  such  as  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  Agence 
Française  de  Développement,  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  Kreditanstalt  für 
Wiederaufbau (KFW), Korea Eximbank, and the World Bank will be an advantage. The team 
leader will report to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and ADB and provide regular work reports as 
required by MOF. He or she will be supported by the national public financial management 
expert and national economist. This assignment will include the following tasks: 
(i)  Review current legal documents, policies, and guidelines on general financial 
management issues applied to official development assistance (ODA) and less-
concessional borrowing.  
(ii)  Review  current  documents,  policies,  and  guidelines  on  project  financial 
preparation  and  analysis,  including  cost  estimates,  financing  plans,  financial 
analyses,  and  assessments  of  project  financial  efficiency  and  viability  in 
investment reports and project feasibility studies. 
(iii)  Assess the capacity of government staff involved in the financial preparation and 
management of ADB-funded projects. 
(iv)  Review international experience on the practices of selected lower-middle-
income countries in project financial management in general and in project 
financial preparation and appraisal in particular.  
(v)  Draft guidelines on project financial preparation and appraisal applied to ADB-
funded investment projects, taking into account sector-specific characteristics. 
(vi)  Draft a streamlined and well-defined manual to guide the financial issues of ODA 
and less-concessional borrowing, including effective models for project financial 
management in accordance with current government and development partner 
regulations. 
(vii)  Prepare  training  materials  on  guidelines  for  the  financial  preparation  and 
appraisal of ADB-funded investment projects and on the manual on the financial 
management issues of ODA and less-concessional borrowing. 
(viii)  Conduct consultation workshops on the draft guidelines on financial preparation 
and  appraisal  for  ADB-funded  investment  projects,  the  draft  manual  on  the 
financial issues of ODA and less-concessional borrowing, and related training 
materials, and incorporate comments from the workshops. 
(ix)  Conduct training-of-trainers courses for staff of MOF, line agencies, and local 
authorities and piloted training courses for the staff of ADB-funded projects in 
selected sectors. 
(x)  Guide national consultants in conducting tracer studies. 
(xi)  Provide oversight and management of the TA; prepare periodic reports to ADB 
and MOF on TA implementation progress, and prepare the TA final report to ADB 
and MOF. 
(xii)  Provide  national  consultants  with  guidelines  for  collecting  the  necessary 
documents and conducting supporting activities.

B.  National Public Financial Management Expert (12 person-months, intermittent)  
2.  The expert should be a qualified financial specialist in public project management or a 
financial economist with extensive experience in the government’s financial procedures and its 
regulations and procedures for managing external borrowing. Postgraduate qualifications in 
economics, public finance, or development studies—and consulting experience with ADB or 
other international financial institutions—will be an advantage. Good command of English is a 
requirement. The expert will support and report to the international public financial management 
specialist, as well as coordinate with relevant departments of MOF and local departments of 
finance. This assignment will include the following tasks: 
(i)  Collect  and  support  the  review  of  current  legal  documents,  policies,  and 
procedures  on  the  government’s  external  borrowing  and  project  financial 
management, and assist reviewing of capacity of government staff involved in the 
financial management of ADB-funded projects. 
(ii)  Provide inputs in the review and suggestions for developing a draft manual on 
the financial issues of ODA and less-concessional borrowing. 
(iii)  Help the international public financial management specialist prepare training 
materials on the draft manual on the financial management issues of ODA and 
less-concessional borrowing. 
(iv)  Support the international public financial management specialist in conducting 
training courses and consultation workshops on the draft manual and related 
training materials. 
(v)  Translate materials and/or provide interpretation for the team leader and the 
training courses if required. 
(vi)  Support MOF in conducting tracer studies to track the uptake of training courses 
by reviewing the project financial management capacity of government staff.  
(vii)  Assist the team leader in preparing periodic reports to ADB and MOF on TA 
implementation progress and in preparing the TA final report to ADB and MOF. 
(viii)  Provide other administrative support as required by the international consultant 
and MOF. 
 
C.  National Economist (8 person-months, intermittent)  
 
3.  The  consultant  should  be  a  qualified  economist  extensively  experienced  with 
government  regulations  and  procedures  on  external  borrowing  and  debt  management. 
Postgraduate qualifications in economics, accounting, or finance and experience in training and 
consulting will be an advantage. Good command of English is a requirement. The economist will 
work under the supervision of the team leader and MOF while collaborating with the national 
public financial management consultant to support the team leader. This assignment will include 
the following tasks: 
(i)  Collect  current  policies,  regulations,  and  procedures  on  project  financial 
management with a focus on those related to project financial preparation and 
appraisal, including project cost estimates, financing plans, financial analyses, 
and assessments of the financial efficiency and viability of projects in investment 
reports  and  project  feasibility  studies.  Support  the  review  of  the  capacity  of 
government staff involved in the financial preparation and appraisal of ADB-
funded investment projects. 
(ii)  Provide inputs for the review process and suggestions for drafting guidelines on 
financial preparation and appraisal applied to investment projects funded by ADB.

Appendix 3  11 
(iii)  Support the international consultant in preparing the draft guidelines on project 
financial preparation and appraisal applied to investment projects and programs 
funded by ADB.  
(iv)  Support  the  international  consultant  in  preparing  training  materials  on  the 
guidelines on project financial preparation and appraisal applied to investment 
projects funded by ADB.  
(v)  Support the international consultant in conducting consultation workshops and 
training courses on the guidelines and related training materials. 
(vi)  Translate materials and/or provide interpretation as required by the international 
economist and for the training courses. 
(vii)  Collaborate with the national public financial management expert in conducting 
tracer  studies  to  track  the  uptake  of  the  training  courses  by  reviewing  the 
capacity of government staff in project financial preparation and appraisal. 
(viii)  Provide other administrative support as required by the international consultant 
and MOF.
